question_text: A quality control inspector examined a random sample of $150$ light bulbs from a recent production batch. In the sample, $6$ bulbs were found to be defective. If $5,000$ light bulbs were produced in total in this batch, which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion?

options.label: Exactly 200 light bulbs in the entire batch are defective.
Exactly 6 light bulbs in the entire batch are defective.
The best estimate for the number of defective light bulbs in the entire batch is 200.
The best estimate for the number of defective light bulbs in the entire batch is 6.

question_text: A factory produces $5,000$ smartphones in a day. To estimate the percentage of defective smartphones produced, a random sample of smartphones is inspected. The percentage of defective smartphones in the sample was found to be $4\%$, with an associated margin of error of $1.5\%$. If $d$ is the actual number of defective smartphones produced in a day, which of the following is most plausible?

A survey of $600$ adults who read books was conducted randomly. The survey found that $25\%$ of the sampled adults prefer mystery novels, with a margin of error of $3\%$. Which of the following is the most plausible conclusion about all adults who read books?

options.label: More than 28% of all adults who read books prefer mystery novels.
Between 22% and 28% of all adults who read books prefer mystery novels.
Less than 20% of all adults who read books prefer mystery novels.
More than 30% of all adults who read books prefer mystery novels.

question_text: A technology company surveyed a random sample of its employees about their daily commute time. The estimated mean commute time was found to be $28$ minutes, with an associated margin of error of $3$ minutes. Which of the following is the best conclusion from these data?

options.label: It is likely that all employees commute between 25 and 31 minutes daily.
It is likely that most employees commute exactly 28 minutes daily.
It is not possible that any employee commutes less than 20 minutes daily.
It is plausible that the mean commute time for all employees is between 25 and 31 minutes.

question_text: A quality control inspector at a factory randomly sampled $250$ light bulbs from a recent production batch. It was found that $8\%$ of the sampled light bulbs were defective. Which of the following conclusions is best supported by the sample data?

options.label: Exactly 8% of all light bulbs produced by the factory are defective.
Fewer than 10% of all light bulbs produced by the factory are defective.
Approximately 8% of the light bulbs in this production batch are defective.
Approximately 8% of all light bulbs produced by all factories are defective.

question_text: A company wants to estimate the number of customers who prefer their new chocolate flavored snack bar over the peanut butter flavor. They randomly sampled $500$ customers and recorded their preference, categorized by age group. The results are shown in the table. If the company has a total customer base of $25,000$ customers, based on this sample, what is the best estimate of the number of customers who prefer the chocolate flavored snack bar?
